stepContents.substepDetail: Do not return to your home or the affected area until authorities declare it safe. Listen to local news and follow official instructions.
When inspecting your property, wear proper protective clothing, including gloves, masks, and long-sleeved shirts, to avoid exposure to ash and debris.
Contact your insurance company as soon as possible to report the damage. Document the damage with photographs and videos before cleaning up or making any repairs.

Take photographs and videos of the damage to your property and belongings. This documentation will be crucial for insurance claims and disaster assistance applications.

While government programs may not provide immediate recovery and relief, we recommend that you still apply for assistance from government programs.

stepContents.substep: Get help by sharing your story below
stepContents.substepDetail: Connect with others who've faced the same natural disaster and express your needs. Together, we can match your needs with generous donors who are looking to provide 1-to-1 support.
Pay attention to your physical and mental health. Wildfire aftermath can be stressful; seek medical attention if you feel unwell.
Don't hesitate to talk to friends, family, or a mental health professional about your feelings. Natural disasters can be emotionally overwhelming, and it's essential to seek support when needed.
Check for cracks or shifts in your home's foundation. Structural integrity is vital for safety.
Look for water damage, warping, or discolouration on walls and ceilings. Address any visible issues promptly.
Do not consume or come into contact with floodwater, as it may contain harmful bacteria or chemicals.
Use gloves, masks, and boots when cleaning up to minimize exposure to contaminants.
Report the damage to your insurance company as soon as possible. Keep records of all communication and documentation.
